hints.content:
###Standard equation of the circle

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation to relate the center and radius.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cfed1de5fce2ce83e5182658316b415cd3651ee9)

 $\begin{align}
a^2+b^2&=c^2\\\\
(x - \blueE{h})^2 + (y - \maroonD{k})^2 &= \goldE {r}^2
\end{align}$

Therefore, the first thing we should do is rewrite the given equation in this form.

### Finding the center and the radius

This is the given equation written in standard form:

$(x-(\blueE{-5}))^2+(y-(\maroonD{-2}))^2=\goldE{2}^2$

Therefore, the center of our circle is at $(\blueE{-5},\maroonD{-2})$ and the radius is $\goldE{2}$.

### Graphing the circle

We graph the circle by dragging the center of the circle to $(\blueE{-5},\maroonD{-2})$ and then dragging the outline so the radius is $\goldE 2$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/48428a2c66f35dd1a3cf288d0ea3cc7efad988d0)

###Standard equation of the circle

A circle is the collection of all points at a distance $\goldE{r}$ from a center $(\blueE{h},\maroonD{k})$.

Therefore, the center of our circle is at $(\blueE{-6},\maroonD{-5})$ and the radius is $\goldE{3}$.

### Graphing the circle

We graph the circle by dragging the center of the circle to $(\blueE{-6},\maroonD{-5})$ and then dragging the outline so the radius is $\goldE{3}$.
